refnamediv.refpurpose: Checks if a value exists in an array

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If the third parameter strict is set to &true; then the in_array function will also check the types of the needle in the haystack.

note.para: If needle is a string, the comparison is done in a case-sensitive manner.
In PHP versions before 4.2.0 needle was not allowed to be an array.

example.title: in_array example
example.programlisting:
<?php
$os = array ("Mac", "NT", "Irix", "Linux");
if (in_array ("Irix", $os)) {
    print "Got Irix";
}
if (in_array ("mac", $os)) {
    print "Got mac";
}
?>
example.para:
The second condition fails because in_array is case-sensitive, so the program above will display:
Got Irix

example.title: in_array with strict example
example.programlisting:
<?php
$a = array('1.10', 12.4, 1.13);

if (in_array('12.4', $a, TRUE)) {
    echo "'12.4' found with strict check\n";
}

if (in_array(1.13, $a, TRUE)) {
    echo "1.13 found with strict check\n";
}
?>
example.para:
This will display:
1.13 found with strict check

example.title: in_array with an array as needle
example.programlisting:
<?php
$a = array(array('p', 'h'), array('p', 'r'), 'o');

if (in_array(array ('p', 'h'), $a)) {
    echo "'ph' was found\n";
}

if (in_array(array ('f', 'i'), $a)) {
    echo "'fi' was found\n";
}

if (in_array('o', $a)) {
    echo "'o' was found\n";
}

/* Outputs:
  'ph' was found
  'o' was found
*/
?>
